approximately three* giving an SEP in the vicinity of 600 watts, depending on

The FCC permits operation at the above mentioned ERP hi cities of less
than 50,000 population with the stipulation that a Grade A signal be maintained over
the metropolitan area to be served.
Of the two companies represented, Dage presented a smaller physical yet
larger electrical transmitter (200 watts peak video output). Their transmitter
was actually manufactured by the Gates Radio Company. It appears to be well
constructed with a high degree of physical accessibility, but did not contain a
sweep generator for alignment nor an aural demodulator. They use the air cooled
Tetrode 4X-150A output stage. The selling price of the transmitter alone was
$8950.00. Several packages were suggested by Dage, priced as follows:
L Transmitter equipment, including transmitter, antenna
(radiator only) and transmission lines, excluding tower - $10,076.00.
2. Film and network programs only, including the above mentioned
transmitter equipment, film camera pick-up system, audio equipment,
miscellaneous equipment and testing accessories, including spare tubes -
$34,904.41.
3. Film, network, live studio presentations (single studio camera).,
included in this package were all the items mentioned above, plus a
studio camera, switch gear, studio audio equipment, and studio lighting
equipment - $45,865.85.
4. Film network for live studio presentations (two camera studio). This
